awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Integrated Thermal Scanning Probe Development
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to commercialize a unique scanning probe capable of mapping thermal properties with nanoscale resolution. A large number of physical science, engineering, and biological materials and phenomena require thermal conductivity and temperature measurements with high spatial resolution and sensitivity.  Yet such measurements are challenging, with conventional thermal probe technology limited to a lateral resolution of only about 100 nanometers.  This phase II project will overcome the major challenges of scanning thermal microscopy.  The intellectual merits of the proposed activity are related to new and innovative designs and processes to realize thermal sensing elements integrated into a scanning probe design.  This design maximizes heat flow from a sample to the probe while minimizing background heat transfer to areas away from the sensor.  These devices will be nanofabricated using both unique and scalable semiconductor processing techniques to minimize the cost of manufacturing and ensure repeatability and reproducibility.  

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the availability of a high resolution thermal measurement tool which will enable scientists and engineers to investigate new materials and develop next-generation products.  In the semiconductor industry, the tool will aid in process monitoring, material characterization, and failure analysis.  The data storage industry will find applications ranging from mapping thermal effects on recording head "fly heights" to the characterization of recording technologies incorporating integrated laser pulsing to the investigation of superparamagnetic effects which limit areal densities.  These are both multi-billion dollar industries that have broad impacts on society.  Moreover, applications of this new technology will be geared towards soft-structure thermal mapping, which is not possible with current technologies because of large probe size.  These measurements will also be ideally suited for medical research.  For example, thermal microscopy of heated gold nanospheres localized in tumors and magnetic nanoparticle tracking inside cellular structures under radio frequency magnetic fields are areas where the impact of this technology will be very high.  Such research has the potential to improve therapeutic interventions targeting a number of diseases.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
• Award Title: SBIR Phase II: Integrated Thermal Scanning Probe Development
  • Federal Award ID: 1256640

Scanning Thermal Microscopy ( SThM) is a mode of AFM to map thermal properties of materials at nanoscale.  The thermal signal from the sample is acquired using a very specialized probe known as Thermal Probe consisting of  a thermal sensing element such as Thermocouple or Thermistor integrated at the tip. The integrated thermal sensing element at the tip facilitates a simultaneous acquisition of surface topography and the thermal images.

The SBIR grant was to develop a Thermal Probe that enables high resolution thermal images at nanoscale. 

Significant Outcomes of the Award  are :

A. Thermal Probe :  The uniqueness and innovation of this  Thermal Probe design lies in the layout of the  thermal sensing element - thermocouple. The  thermocouple is aligned vertically, in-line with the apex of the tip, to maximize thermal sensitivity, resolution an probe lifetime. Figure 1 shows a cross- sectional,  top and  side view SEM.  The embedded Nanorod acting as one leg of the thermocouple is the most critical part of the design.  

The key features of these  Thermal Probe are :

  1. Compatibility with all commercial and home built AFMs.
  2. Facilitate imaging in various modes of AFM operation  such as ? Contact Mode, Non-contact mode and Hybrid Modes.
  3. Nanoscale mapping of  Thermal Conductivity Contrast and Temperature Contrast. Figure 2 and 3 are shown as representation.
  4. Actual Temperature measurement  more than 700?C . 
  5. Advanced Local Thermal Analysis  ( LTA) ? simultaneous heating with laser  and temperature measurement.

 B.       SThM Module :  In order to process the signal from thermocouple  an electronics module was developed. It is a two step processing of the electronics signal from ?V to 10V ( max). The control functions and an averaged live temperature display are provided through a Bluetooth connected tablet. The module is compatible with all commercial AFMs. Figure 4 shows the  SThM Module and the Tablet display. 

  C.  Temperature Calibration Unit  :  This is first time in the market that a real temperature measurement at nanoscale is possible. As part of the SThM module development, a temperature calibration unit was develeoped to calibrate the Probe Thermocouple with a known Thermocouple. 

 D.  Thermal Characterizer:  In order to offer a complete solution to the users a microfabricated  Thermal Characterizer was developed to  set up the thermal module and to verify the thermal probes.

Broader Impact:

 A.      For  the Researchers :  Growth in the Scanning Thermal Microscopy has been  limited due to non-availability of versatile , sensitive and high resolution Thermal Probes.  The thermal probe developed under this grant has overcome many of these limitations. Based on some of the recently published papers, the new technology probe technology is helping the researchers to identify new areas of research in material sciences and bio ?sciences.  Since it is new technology,  faster growth will require sustained application and development support from the AFM manufacturers and the Awardee.

B.      For the Awardee : The Awardee offers a complete solution for SThM applications.  This would have not been possible without the NSF SBIR support. This product is  not only differentiator from other probe manufacturers but also helps bonding with AFM manufacturers.  The new applications that have been identified such as Local Thermal Analysis is expected to  add in the  company growth.

 


Last Modified: 08/28/2019
Modified by: Ami Chand

por.por_txt_cntn:
Award Title: SBIR Phase II: Integrated Thermal Scanning Probe Development
Federal Award ID: 1256640


Scanning Thermal Microscopy ( SThM) is a mode of AFM to map thermal properties of materials at nanoscale.  The thermal signal from the sample is acquired using a very specialized probe known as Thermal Probe consisting of  a thermal sensing element such as Thermocouple or Thermistor integrated at the tip. The integrated thermal sensing element at the tip facilitates a simultaneous acquisition of surface topography and the thermal images.

The SBIR grant was to develop a Thermal Probe that enables high resolution thermal images at nanoscale. 

Significant Outcomes of the Award  are :

A. Thermal Probe :  The uniqueness and innovation of this  Thermal Probe design lies in the layout of the  thermal sensing element - thermocouple. The  thermocouple is aligned vertically, in-line with the apex of the tip, to maximize thermal sensitivity, resolution an probe lifetime. Figure 1 shows a cross- sectional,  top and  side view SEM.  The embedded Nanorod acting as one leg of the thermocouple is the most critical part of the design.  

The key features of these  Thermal Probe are :

Compatibility with all commercial and home built AFMs.
Facilitate imaging in various modes of AFM operation  such as ? Contact Mode, Non-contact mode and Hybrid Modes. 
Nanoscale mapping of  Thermal Conductivity Contrast and Temperature Contrast. Figure 2 and 3 are shown as representation.
Actual Temperature measurement  more than 700?C .  
Advanced Local Thermal Analysis  ( LTA) ? simultaneous heating with laser  and temperature measurement.


 B.       SThM Module :  In order to process the signal from thermocouple  an electronics module was developed. It is a two step processing of the electronics signal from ?V to 10V ( max). The control functions and an averaged live temperature display are provided through a Bluetooth connected tablet. The module is compatible with all commercial AFMs. Figure 4 shows the  SThM Module and the Tablet display. 

  C.  Temperature Calibration Unit  :  This is first time in the market that a real temperature measurement at nanoscale is possible. As part of the SThM module development, a temperature calibration unit was develeoped to calibrate the Probe Thermocouple with a known Thermocouple. 

 D.  Thermal Characterizer:  In order to offer a complete solution to the users a microfabricated  Thermal Characterizer was developed to  set up the thermal module and to verify the thermal probes.

Broader Impact:

 A.      For  the Researchers :  Growth in the Scanning Thermal Microscopy has been  limited due to non-availability of versatile , sensitive and high resolution Thermal Probes.  The thermal probe developed under this grant has overcome many of these limitations. Based on some of the recently published papers, the new technology probe technology is helping the researchers to identify new areas of research in material sciences and bio ?sciences.  Since it is new technology,  faster growth will require sustained application and development support from the AFM manufacturers and the Awardee.

B.      For the Awardee : The Awardee offers a complete solution for SThM applications.  This would have not been possible without the NSF SBIR support. This product is  not only differentiator from other probe manufacturers but also helps bonding with AFM manufacturers.  The new applications that have been identified such as Local Thermal Analysis is expected to  add in the  company growth.
